metadata.title: The Philosophy of Luddism: The Case of the West of England Woolen Workers, ca. 1790-1809

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the resistance of woolen workers to technological changes in the form of machinery, which threatened their livelihoods and traditional work practices.

dependent_variables.displaced: The spinning jenny displaced around nine of ten warp spinners and thirteen of fourteen abb (weft) spinners. The scribbling engine displaced fifteen of sixteen scribblers. The gig mill and shearing frame made many shearmen redundant.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Many workers were left without jobs as their skills became obsolete due to machinery.

key_themes: Impact of mechanization on traditional industries
Moral and economic arguments against machinery
text_fragments: The vigorous opposition of the English woolen workers 'to introduction of improvements' is well known.
The woolen workers believed that 'A trade or manufacture is deemed valuable to a country in proportion to the number of hands it employs.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the resistance of woolen workers to mechanization, highlighting their moral and economic arguments against the introduction of machinery, which they believed threatened their livelihoods and traditional work practices.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of industrialization and mechanization in the woolen industry.
historical_context.institutional_context: There were existing statutes and regulations that the workers attempted to use to block the introduction of machinery.

outcomes.main_findings: The woolen workers' resistance to machinery was based on both economic and moral grounds, as they believed it threatened their livelihoods and the traditional structure of their industry.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that the resistance to mechanization was not merely blind vandalism but a rational response to the threat posed by machinery to the workers' livelihoods and social status.
